poem:
Lost on the Line

A whistle threads through the countryside,  
carrying Howells's notes into the air.  
Music, like memories, sometimes misplaced—  
melodies strewn over tracks,  
untethered echoes in Gloucestershire.  
Yet isn't it in these half-heard,  
half-remembered whispers  
that evening softens  
into a quartet, finding its way  
through the years,  
a composition of small losses?
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. In essence, his first effort, which he wrote as a young man in the summer of 1916, was lost on a train journey between Lydney (his birthplace) and Gloucester.
